philosophers_schema.name: Aristotle
philosophers_schema.description: Unlike his teacher Plato, Aristotle had a natural approach in philosophy. He was interested in biology, specially studying sea creatures.

philosophers_schema.name: Immanuel Kant
philosophers_schema.description: He gave an objection to Anselm's ontological argument.

philosophers_schema.name: Moses Maimonides
philosophers_schema.description: He believed that God's nature will always remain unknown because it is beyond human understanding.

philosophers_schema.name: René Descartes
philosophers_schema.description: Cogito ergo sum (I think, therefore I am). He founded the view of rationalism, and believed that reason is the key to understanding the universe.

philosophers_schema.name: Baruch Spinoza
philosophers_schema.description: He studied the philosophy of the philosophers who came before him specially Blaise Pascal and Thomas Hobbes. His solution was absolute monism instead of Descartes' dualism.

philosophers_schema.name: John Locke
philosophers_schema.description: Established the basis of political liberalism and philosophical empiricism.

philosophers_schema.name: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
philosophers_schema.description: Filled the gap between the God-centered world and the rationalism caused by the scientific revolution.

philosophers_schema.name: Juana Inés de la Cruz
philosophers_schema.description: Argued that throughout the Bible there is no trace of the prohibition of education for women.

philosophers_schema.name: George Berkeley
philosophers_schema.description: Proposed the concept of Subjective Idealism and believed that material objects exist only in the form of perception.

philosophers_schema.name: Voltaire
philosophers_schema.description: Was one of the key figures of the rationalism of the Age of Enlightenment and one of the founders of the modern liberal tradition.
